reviews.text: Walking around the Olympic village and seeing the architecture and the sheer size of these buildings is amazing. With all there is to see and experience, it's a must see after the great wall.

The Beijing National Aquatics Center also officially known as the National Aquatics Center, and colloquially known as the Water Cube(Chinese: 水立方), is an aquatics center that was built alongside Beijing National Stadiumin the Olympic Green for the swimming competitions of the 2008 Summer Olympics. Despite its nickname, the building is not an actual cube, but a cuboid (a rectangular box). Ground was broken on December 24, 2003, and the Center was completed and handed over for use on January 28, 2008.Swimmers at the Water Cube broke 25 world records during the 2008 Olympics.
An amazing piece of art and architecture. A view at night is much beautiful than ever.

The main pool where Phelps made history looks the exactly how he left it, not even one maintenance job can be found. For the winter olympic games of 2022 it will be converted to an ice ice rink.

The other pools are now used by general public! Very crowded by the way but people seams happy!

A very fun place to visit for a bit, just make sure it's not sunny or even if it is, do make sure to bring an umbrella, there is literally no shade at all. Apart from that the experience is worth a bit of effort of walking all the way to the aquarium unless you pay for the carriage.
One of the top universities of China. Long history, high reputation and strong academy.
The best university in China, not one of the - I graduated from the place :-)

One of the best university i have ever visited. They have all the resources any students will need in their college time with all the latest technologies from AR to production of products. Their labs are amazing with largest campus in the world.
The best in China and top in Asia.

The university was first established 1911. University location Haidian district, Beijing, People Republic of China. World top level university. It is a public university. 
University Motto "Self discipline and social commitment ". 
University campus looking so amazing.  Transportation & communication best. University campus local area very large. Any students for dream university.

There is a subway station right at the stadium. Very convenient. 

There are several things to do there... stadium tour, 3D museum, etc. The admission fee is not too expensive. 

The structure is just impressive.

Very beautiful architecture, one of the most aesthetically pleasing stadiums in the world. Across from it is the National Aquatics center where Michael Phelps an Olympic record 8 gold medals during the 2008 Olympics in Beijing. It's a lot nicer at night.

The national stadium has a very impressive architecture and was held the Summer Olympic Games in 2008 - it’ll be also the host for the Winter Olympic Games in 2022. 

Please be advised to go thru the checkpoints “without” buying a ticket cuz the ticket for the so called “birds nest” is in front of the National stadium and costs u 80 Yuan.
Very attractive and good design ... after event the stadium still usefull and still many people also tourists visit here
It was a great place to go and see, there's a museum and places to eat, wort a look at the birds nest
Walking around the Olympic village and seeing the architecture and the sheer size of these buildings is amazing. With all there is to see and experience, it's a must see after the great wall.

Wow good cctv camera china

The tallest CCTV tower is 234 m high with a floor area of 465,000 m² and consists of a series of horizontal and vertical sections, which establishes it as an earthbound structure and not a ‘skyscraper’. This tower contains administration, news, broadcasting, studios, programme production areas, staff facilities and parking. A public media museum will be located on the cantilevered part of the building.

The neighbouring TVCC tower is 194 m high with 95,000 m² floor space. Its programme includes a 300-room Mandarin Oriental hotel designed by Lim, Teo & Wilkes (containing two restaurants, a suspended champagne sky bar and a ballroom surrounded by water), a visitor centre, a 1,500-seat public theatre, a digital cinema and exhibition and conference facilities.

The remainder of the site surrounding the building was developed into a media park with outdoor filming areas, theatres, production facilities and public entertainment areas.
Amazing building, bypassing the traditional top down contrast.
Best broadcast facilities and on time in-depth news source about China
It is very big building which is 54th story and 230m high.

The temple depicts many departments of hell... and 'surreal' is not a strong enough word. For example, there is a "department for 15 ways to implement death" and you just have to see it for yourself. Well worth the trip, and I'll be bringing visitors here again.
Very interesting temple.

This Temple is for King Dongyue and his family. It has many statues and stands out against surrounding modern buildings. The ticket is ¥10(the East entrance). If you want to hire a tourist guide, you can buy tickets at the West entrance, ¥40. The WC is at the rear of the Temple.
My favourite temple in Beijing, lots to see and there's a mall not too far for lunch ;)
This is one of the most interesting temples in Beijing, interesting depictions of Daoist hell and awesome steles.

Seems to be a popular place for the local Beijing residents to go for a walk in the park. Free of charge to enter. When walking west to east, Google maps leads you down a somewhat deserted pathway (so initially a bit disconcerting) towards an eastern exit that was a bit of a surprise - a broken down door that you could step thru to successfully exit to the roadway. But I guess that was better than running into a locked door (dead-end).
My favorite place to walk around when we are in Beijing.  A wonderful non tourist spot.  A must go, there is always something going on.

Lovely park with great scenery and people dancing and playing games. There are many places to sit in the shade and relax and some beautiful art pieces. I was told the park is dedicated to the story of how there were 9 suns and a hero shot all down but one in order to help the people on earth who were too hot.
nice and quite park

We went here in Feb 2016, It is a magical place. We went very early in the morning it was very cold. We saw people exercising by doing various martial arts and using the gym equipment in the park. The temple is an amazing structure. There were other things of interest around the park with information plaques. The park is open 24hrs and is free of charge. If this review was helpful, please like.

We went to the golden mask dynasty that was a stage performance at the location.

It was magnificent, great story and performers. The stage and the props that were used was amazing. They were unexpected and really provided a big and dramatic effects to the stage.

I watched the Song Dynasty show. It was well worth seeing, the moving stage make for an one of a kind show. I the story they told was the typical cliche love story but the dancers were decent so I was able to endure.

Lots of things to do. However, only bring kids that are over eight or quite tall.  Rides are limited by height and if you're planning on bringing little ones less than 1.1m tall then don't bother.  You'll pay full price for adults and there will be no rides for the kids

Golden mask dynasty show was awesome. A dance drama love story of king and queen is beautifully portrayed in this show. Queen’s sacrifice to save the country and people makes it fascinating. The sound, lights, costumes, acting, dances and water flow effects are beyond words. If you visit Beijing, don’t miss this epic show.

I went in the autumn on a Thursday, all rides were open and queues were short. They do wait for full rides before starting them, so time getting in a queue strategically. There are some serious rollercoasters and a good amount of other rides too including an amazing platform that takes you high above the park. We stayed for the golden mask dynasty show at the end which was included in our day passes and it was totally spectacular, a real surprise. It would be worth the entrance fee just for the show. The shows in the park itself range from awful to medium though, but might be better if you understand Chinese. The kids area is quite funny, there's a rip off of it's a small world, I rode that twice gleefully.
Great building with four floors full of interesting things to visit. Very good for children of any age.
Very interesting and well maintained place. You'll find all the technology which might be you are using knowingly or unknowningly. Everything thing at one place. Must visit once.
Must see once very nice place
Great buildings with awasome floor
Lively place to watch.

A very enjoyable and hip area in Beijing to walk around. We didn't go with a plan and just ended up meandering around and into different galleries. There were some interesting artists displaying work and a large number of public statues and graffiti art. Lots of coffee shops for a rest or hot drink. Was a nice contrast to some of the more historical sites to see a more contemporary part of the city.

Must try in Beijing if you love art. 
Do spend a day and explore all the alleys. You never know what you'll find. 
P.s. some galleries may be open/closed. They're either preparing for an exhibition or have finished one

This are is changing constantly as I was told by a local guy who lives here .

There were some factories around and now they are turning into stores and restaurants.

There is an old train station with an actual train and they changed to a cafeteria, it's kinda cool.

I highly recommend this place.
Interesting place full of art shops, galleries and caffes. Looks more European than Chinese. You can can spend a few relaxing hours there enjoying art fusion.

Decided to visit reading previous comments. It is like little town, never ending. Lot of galleries, couple of monuments....nothing special to impress....would recommend visit just if you want to loose day out
No vp

What can I say? Simply can’t have enough of the delicious pita pies prepared at sun bake pita bakery. I tried the cheese and the Kishk. Both tasted amazing. The place is clean and the service comes with a generous smile. Can’t wait for my next Edmonton visit to raid the delicacies they have to offer. Thoroughly enjoyed it.

Had to wait in line for about 10 minutes. Big menu with a large selection of Pita's. You can choose a basic Pita, or pay a little more and get it fully loaded. Option of cut like a pizza or folded in half. Very flavorful because it is backed in a big wood fired type oven. The size of one is a good snack. Order two and I think it could be a meal.
Simple and Amazing! I recommend the wrap with zatar, olive, tomato.... Service is great too! I hike all the way to the north once a month only to eat there.
Best baked pitas in Edmonton. Not much seating space at lunch. Food is 5 stars all the way.
Love love love this place! Amazing pizza style pita bread creations, and delectable desserts. Try something different at this Northside hidden gem! :)
Very nice and unique Sichuan taste Foods. Must try guys ...
Definitely one of the best Sichuan restaurant in town. The hot pot restaurant on the 3rd floor is also excellent.
Solid Sichuan place next to April Gourmet. Wide and diverse selection of dishes, from mild to very spicy. They also do take out.
菜品质量长期保持一致 环境宽敞舒适，价格适中。
Nice place, specially in summer because of the terrace. An oasis of peace in the noisy Sanlitun area of Beijing. It's worth trying the gazpacho (cold spanish tomato soup) and the iberian ham bocata.
Favorite sandwich place in Beijing. Try their tuna melt.
Excelente local, muy bohemio y la comida excelente, les recomiendo el sub de carne y queso, pueden conseguir las gaseosas y cervezas más baratas de la calle de bares
this is good place for Halal food and specially turkish food here. Although there are many other foreign resturants available here.
Good place in BJ for foodies who love Turkish varieties
Perfect restaurant
Good
Amazing!!!
Just a great place and great food!

Thanks to hotel concierges who recommended this place to us that we’ve been coming here every time we’re stayin World Trade Center. Every dish has its own flavor and it’s so authentic to the core of style Beijing, which is comfort and delicate and delicious. The portion is generous, the price is beyond decent, the location is in the center of biz and hotels jungle. If you ever tried Beijing cuisine, you know this is one of the best, if you haven’t, what you’re waiting for?!
Spent 5 Chinese New Years here, cozy and friendly place, nice memory!

The food is delicious and inexpensive.  The menu of mostly northern style Chinese dishes is extensive.  Great place to grab dinner with friends after work. A nice dinner for 2 - 3 people costs about $20.    You won't be disappointed.  

Note:  It's freezing cold in Beijing during the winter and it can be quite brutal to go outside to eat.  Xiaowang's does not advertise this but they will deliver to nearby hotels like the Shangri-La, the Millennium or nearby apartments.
Very easy local place food not great but reliable. Expats love this place.
Great food, great atmosphere, great band.

地元チベット料理
ヤクのバター、ヤクの舌など
要说口味其实也就这样，辣的比较多，上次带老人来吃，他们都不爱吃辣的，人的确是很多，提前10天定的位子。价格很实惠，红烧肉味道很赞
歌舞很好，人也热情
Beautiful restaurant, amazing food!
Delicious food
Delicious Peking duck cut and served at the table. Spinning wheel on the table to share different curries and rice.

Delicious Peking duck in Beijing. You'll have to take a number and wait in front of the restaurant for a table (at least we had to - on a saturday night, don't know about about other days). The peking duck comes with vegetables, sauces and pancakes (it does not say that in the menu, just so you know as there wasn't anyone speaking English) and was real good. A chef comes to your table and cuts the duck into pieces in front of you. One duck plus some appetizers was enough for three persons.

Best Peking Duck, period. Duck has no gamey taste and very crispy skin that does not taste over oily. If you had great Peking duck anywhere in the world before, I'm certain this place redefine the definition of excellence. 

And to top it all, other dishes as well as ambience is great as well.

Yes it’s true, amazing duck and a definite must have for Beijing visitors. Also the Spicey meat is fantastic. 
Great service even though the waitress didn’t speak much English but with google translate we managed easily. 
We walked in without reservation which was not a problem but to be fair it was Sunday 6pm, not sure how it works later/ on Friday or Saturday. 
The wine was ok, white, not quite cold enough but didn’t leave a sour taste (figuratively speaking). 
Total bill for two around 650, not cheap but with duck, dumplings, desert and wine/beer worth it.

Dadong
While I confess that I’m not a Peking duck expert; this place set the bar high. The overall ambiance was fantastic; with beautiful colorful lanterns decorating the dining room. They brought over the starter dishes before the duck; we ordered cauliflower; and a beef and fried rice. We had a 1/2 duck for three people and it was outstanding. The waiter gave some suggestions on typical preparation; in the pancake; in the sesame roll; and in the sugar spread. They all were fantastic. They carve and serve the duck table side. My only complaint is that this is one of the only restaurants I visited where they would not help you find a cab home. As such, we were walking around endlessly as no cabs would stop for us, and the street wasn’t really that busy. We finally took the subway home which was fine; but not an ideal way to end the evening in a foreign city trying to find a way home. At the very least; at such an expensive restaurant for many foreigners they should have a private car service you can hire home.

The place came highly recommend and did not disappoint. The server helped every step of the way explaining what we should order, how we should eat it, and even cut of some of my sons food for him. The service AND the food were both top notch. My 5 y/o fell in love with the dumplings and even asked if we could go back the next day!

I can highly recommend this restaurant! By far the best roasted duck I had! In addition the staff is also very friendly and helpful and the atmosphere is really nice. I will definitely always come back when I'm in Beijing.
Love the place, great food. I recommend the noodles with peanut sauce for sure and all dim sum was great overall.

It's too busy... They won't give you the attention the focus your looking for. 

I was disappointed.
Loved the Xiao long bao (plain pork) ! Very delicious, especially the chocolate ones, which I highly recommend!

The place that could never be wrong when you're in a delicacy hunger. Their services staff are at least 4 levels/types and the food is typical Cantonese cuisine. The crab one is a can't miss, seasonal seafood is a nice surprise.

Great place for Chinese dumplings and other dishes. The restaurant is on the expensive side as for Chinese pricing but it is well worth it. The management speaks English also so it is easy to communicate. Menu's are clear and with pictures so you can also pick and choose what to eat. Great for both locals and foreigners.

The free wine tasting is getting more stringy nowadays. When I tasted the slightly higher price one the employee gave me few drops
only. After 20 minutes I went back the boss told me I tasted before. The rest of wine for tasting also all low price one. Therefore i didn’t buy at all as never has chance to taste a better quality.

Had a good experience to learn about different wine labels during the last grand tasting event. I lost count with the numbers of alcohol I have tasted. Always get my bottles with the help from knowledgeable and friendly staffs.
Well knowledgable staff and good ambience. You also get to taste the liqours whilst shopping. Very friendly staffs, especially Ms. Tee.
Very very very lousy service. The salesman is very rude. No wine testing service at all. Feel like cheated by the company and the viewers.
Selection is great for wine, sake, beer, etc but moscato only 3 variants. Sad. 😔

One of the most beautiful places in Beijing.

 Go early in the morning, take snacks, and spend all day here. 

Lots of different buildings to go through and learn about. A beautiful rose garden in the centre. Perfect weather in spring.

34 yuan entrance fee (RMB) well worth the price.

After it's rebuilding this scenario had become one of my favorite places in Beijing. Art, history, peace, harmony, community, old traditions... everything remains like a calm morning even outside the city is moving faster and faster.  You can stay hours looking the beauty of this non corner building which seems not to have home or ending. Just one concern, too many tourists taking photos... Disgusting.

If you go to the Temple of Heaven and miss this hall, you haven’t actually been to the Temple! The Hall of Prayer is the iconic building in the park and represents the location where the emperor would pray. It’s the tallest building in the park and often crowded, but it’s still gorgeous and worth a visit!

In my eyes one of the most wonderful places in Beijing! The park is very well maintained and the different areas and temples outstanding beautiful. During the day you can see old Beijingers play traditional games or dances. A must-see of the capital of China! Important side note: The most famous Temple of Heaven closes already at 1600h while the park remains open.

Such a beautiful and majestic place. 
It really look otherworldly. 
The attention to detail from the square barrier (Earth) and the circular temple in the middle (heavens), nothing is left to chance. 
And around the palace, people enjoying their daily routine of playing card and dominos. 
Also a park where the elderly can play various games or even partake in aerobics if not tai Chi.

Great little walking park along the old Ming Dynasty City Wall. The wall's in great shape, all things considered (probably got restored recently), and the walking paths are well-maintained. Lots of families make use of it and I saw several old folks exercise groups and dance groups. Really nice for an evening walk, and for the part that's along the wall, it's free.

Not many people. Ticket only 10 yuan. Not very big. You can tell most of it is redone, if you've been to Xi'an you can skip this. Such a shame the government destroyed the wall back in the day. Spring is best time to go. You can still see some of the old wall on the Westside, but can't go there. Has  bathrooms.

It's directly accessible from exit B of the Chongwenmen metro station on line 2 or 5. From here, you'll be on the west end of the park. Continue east along the length of the 1.5 km section of wall from Chongwenmen to Dongbianmen. It's the only remaining section of wall from the Ming dynasty and used to form the inner city wall. It's a nice stroll and you'll see many locals. At the east end, the gate tower has a 10 RMB entrance fee. The Red Gate gallery is located in the tower. Not a major attraction for tourists.

What a shame that we Chinese ourselves destroyed the Peking City with savage madness and stupidity! In year 2000, Beijing gov restored the Wall with bricks that had been taken by Beijing city's own residents, who themselves tore down the Wall  in the 1950s, for building a small house just to improve their living condition, as part of the revolution led by Chairman Mao to be against Feudalism. Is it ironic that Sicheng Liang who had protected Japan's Kyoto and Nara from nuclear bomb can't stop Chinese stupidity dismantling the Peking City Wall? 60 years ago, we destroyed all of the Wall, which had been lasting for about 500 years, because it represented the Feudalism in our leaders' view. 50 years ago, we restored part of the Wall to what it seems to have been lasted for several hundreds years to attract tourism.

In 1950s, the "Liang-Chen planning(梁陈方案)" was not executed for the leaders short sight. Liang-Chen planning(梁陈方案), initiated by Sicheng Liang and Zhanxiang Chen, was an overall city proposal, which aims to remain all Peking City as a whole as it was before 1949, and to propose the location of Central Government near Gongzhufen(公主坟) and supporting transportation facilities and residential area around Gongzhufen, minimizing the transportation distance from work for government staff. Because Peking City, before 1949, is the only and unique well-preserved city that has been lasting for nearly 500 years and is not suitable to stand large scale construction. The supporting facility in old Peking City was too out-dated for running a government and because it could sabotage the whole City. Then Chairman Mao turned the planning and took Russian's planning which views Peking City as a useless and meaningless ancient City and proposes to construct all the government buildings alongside Chang'an Street. Then nightmare began. Wall built in Ming Dynasty was tore down by residences themselves in Peiking City to have additional living room.
Great walking area

The museum is a decent, but its exhibits feel limited. If odd looking animatronic dinosaurs are your thing, than pay this place a visit. There are a good number of dinosaur skeletons on display, but it’s too obvious they’re replicas. Don’t be fooled by the cafeteria sign; there’s no food down there, just an empty, sketchy open area where parents and kids sit on the floor and doze off. In fact, there isn’t any proper food in the museum- only a few snacks- so make sure you plan ahead. What I do like though is the inclusion of an aquarium in the basement. It might take a bit of navigating to find, but it is quite large and definitely worth a look.

Exciting in some ways, and disappointing in other ways! Admission is free, and the building is pretty easy to find. It's about a ten minute walk from 珠市口 subway station (line 7). There is very little English signage, but I used my google translate app's camera function to get a rough translation. The aquarium is amazingly pathetic and sad, don't bother going downstairs to see it unless you want to feel pity for some fish. However, the other exhibits, particularly the human origins exhibit, were really cool!!!

The museum is mainly directed at school age children in my opinion, with the displays being brief and easy to grasp, but of course the adults can still find a lot to see and enjoy here. The entry is free, which is really a great benefit. On the downside the museum was pretty crowded.

This museum is a bit of a disappointment. The museum is not very large, so only 45 or so minutes are needed. The robot dinosaur exhibit was pretty cool, as well as the Brazilian fish fossil one. But, the other exhibits were just cheap plastic sculptures. The gift shop was also very overpriced, and the staff were always unavailable. The aquarium was terrible, as the water was spilling onto the floor, and the fish were in crammed tanks meant for goldfish. And whatever you do, DO NOT GO DOWNSTAIRS. Unless you like seeing forensic stuff, like preserved fetuses and corpses, don't go there. I almost threw up, and I couldn't finish my lunch!
Worth visiting once but as others mention, needs updating.

We had the privilege of being the guests of our colleagues at the Beijing Centers for Disease Control at this restaurant last week.  I have to admit that of all the meals that I have had in China, this was by far the best that I have ever experienced.  The host was able to give us a brief tour of the building explaining the history of the place.  I believe that it was more than 300 years old.  The Beijing Duck was amazing.  The crisp skin served with the sugar and then the sliced duck meat rolled in a pancake with the plum sauce and vegetables were great.  The other foods that were served were equally good.  The fish was tender and didn't have many bones.  The potatoes and the vegetables were perfectly cooked.  The liquor that was a part of many toasts that evening was quite good.  Overall, this was an evening that I shall not forget - unless I develop some mental disease.  It was worth the wait.

$$. Xianyukou Bianyifang 鲜鱼口便宜坊  is a Chinese national treasure and a 600 year-old absolutely must visit restaurant experience in Beijing for Peking Duck. They laboriously and meticulously prepared entrées and side dishes that are most authentic, that very proudly and perfectly represents Chinese Beijing cuisine. This restaurant is very popular and can get really busy, but the service is excellent and has an incredibly professional, dedicated and highly knowledgable staff that can answer any question you may have and provide recommendations too.
Established in 1416, the original Bianyifang used to be a small workshop, which produced duck and chicken food in Mishihutong (米市胡同), Caishikou, Beijing. In 1827, its owner Sun Zijiu (孙子久) began to extend its business and established a bigger restaurant, where Peking Duck and Spanish and French Style Duck Liver (西法鸭肝) are its "signature dishes".
Xianyukou Bianyifang in 1855 was established in Qianmen, Beijing by a Wang family, who hired a chef of the original Bianyifang. The restaurant has carried the Beijing cuisine tradition from the Qing dynasty to its modern-day form. Due to the fame of the original Bianyifang, many restaurants named themselves "Bianyifang", among which, Xianyukou Bianyifang 鲜鱼口便宜坊 is the one that exists today.
The better Peking duck experience in Beijing compared to quan ju de. Duck is great, and the other side dishes are also well done.
It's very taste .. New experience .. Thanks .!!
Nice roasted duck restaurant with 800 years of history.

 Go early in the morning, take snacks, and spend all day here.

I can only speak for the club event on the friday evenings (Lolita) but I loved it, the venue is amazing and the atmosphere was great. Prices for drinks are okay for Paris. Our new favourite!
Extremely famous restaurant, historical place. I was there for one private party in the evening, so everything was of that red lighting.
While the service was nice, food was strictly ok. Place was barely half full of customers so it's not as popular as I believe it once was.
Feeing the spirit of the Gold  chic cabaret  time. All is floral.

A delightfull experience of Parisian service in a lavish traditional art-deco atmosphere. "Goose" Foie gras, not duck, soup, and then Salad Croquants. No alcolhol to change my palette until we enjoyed our dessert of fresh assorted cheeses and sorbet.

Love walking into a Starbucks and smelling the fresh coffee. This location was clean and the staff friendly. Coffee was made to order and correctly made for this picky coffee drinker lol. This spot has an area for when you are wanting to socialize or break out the computer/books and do some studying while sipping on a latte. Only problem I seen was the drive through and parking area are very tight but couldn't take a star away just for that. Keep it up at this location cause my little girl and I will definitely be back for our coffee.
Always fast, friendly, and informative! Their coffee is great and their snacks are always yummy! Mobile pickup through their app is always very convenient as well!

Yummy but prices need to stop going up, they  are beyond being a very successful business that has millions of people addicted and stopping for ine of their many yummy beverages and foods almost every day like its crack, stop being greedy with the cost increase of everything, PLEASE. I want to be able to afford my coffee "crack" lol just playing, kinda. Attention there's no illegal drugs served at any Starbucks facility
... that I'm aware of!
Very friendly service. Got the order correct. Fast.
Rude, impersonal staff, slow service, dirty restrooms. The food is blah, you get better quality food at much lower prices at McDonalds or any of the other fast food chains in the area.

Wickipedia claims that this obelisk is ten stories. I don't believe it having seen it. There is a very nice bas relief at the bottom symbolizing the revolutionary struggle of the Chinese People. There is a barricade around it as well as a guard posted. If you want to get an insider's look at a Chinese Prison be sure to attempt to go and touch the Obelisk, which is said to bring 10 years of an incredible weight loss program.

I truly enjoyed visiting the Forbidden City during my travels to Beijing! China has such a rich history and you can truly step right into the culture by visiting this historic site. It is massive so you can literally spend a good part of your day in there and still not see everything. Be aware that tickets sell out extremely fast so be sure to arrive very early to secure your entrance. Our tour guide told us that 80,000 people visit the Forbidden City daily! I highly recommend this tourist site for your Beijing travels!

A marvelous place. You gonna spend hours in this place. Hundreds of buildings, landscapes,  stairs, gardens, all well preserved.  The stores inside sell articles, drinks and food for a reasonable price.  Foreigners must buy the ticket that costs RMB 40 in March. Don't forget you passport, and don't carry any forbidden stuff. The security is very effective.

This is probably one of the most famous landmarks in Beijing. The historic and cultural significance of this place makes this without a doubt, a must visit place for any tourist. The sprawling grounds that are opened to visitors are quite well kept considering the age and massive amounts of human traffic. We engaged an official guide, not one of the touts standing around, and had a blast listening to the various stories as we walked around. For the unfamiliar, a guide is the way to go, as the place is huge, and you get to ask questions. 

We spent nearly a full day there, and had to still skip some of the exhibitions inside that requires payment. Yes, on top of the entrance fee, there are exhibitions here and there that requires a small fee as well. Don't be daunted by the tight security, and massive crowds, as this is really one of those places you have to see at the very least once in your life.

It wasn't caked the Forbidden City for nothing... Opulence at its grandest... In the heart of Beijing.
Its a must see!!
Expect to spend at least half a day inside of you want to get a good understanding of the place.
One can buy tickets at the counter on the left just before the entrance, by showing your passport... Wasn't trouble at all.

Here is our very negative experience - never travel here at bank holiday ... We come at Saturday lunch time to find out that the tickets were sold out ... The service guys told us to come at 8 next day that there is 1000 tickets at the window. Otherwise you can buy tickets online but for that you need to have Chinese bank account and still there is just 80K tickets in total. So we come Sunday at 7 to find out a lot of people but still we was between the first ones. After waiting one hour they start to let people in just to find out that the tickets are sold out again. Even we clearly saw some locals buy tickets. The guards laugh to our face and did not let us in ... So we basically did not saw forbidden city but our experience with it is very bad ...
Very peaceful and interesting place to learn about a key figure that shaped Chinese culture. It is well worth having a wander around these beautiful gardens and taking it all in.
One of my favorite places to visit in Beijing. Easy to get to by subway. Beautiful place to stroll and learn history.
The temple is around the corner of 雍和宮. If you are keen to explore somewhere off the tourist path this is where you could visit.

Beautiful ancient temple, so inspirational and full of history, one of the most beautiful temples in Beijing and while China. Long queues for tickets , better to visit in early morning, leads crowded )) near the Lama Temple
Nice environment, good to see and read about the ancient historic scholars. Worth a visit if you have the time. Not difficult to get there by train and walk with GPS. Also near the Lama Temple.

It's organized well and with a few English signs. The 2nd floor has a history and function the police organization. The 3rd floor has a memorial to police servicemen who died while in service. The 4th floor has a display of weapons.

Growing up going there every month! Its a perfect size for cisiters. Not too big, actrully the smallest national art gallery I've been after growing up and traveled. It does put up good exhibitions, nice flow. Its a exhibition hall really. If you want to see national treasure art its all at the China National Museum on Tiananmen Square.  Its a prue art gallery with constaintly exhibitions of current artists.

An amazing art museum! It's free, all you need to bring is your passport to get a ticket. They host a wide array of different exhibits, usually highlighting Chinese artists, but you can also expect to see foreign art there, too. Be sure to check the website before you go, so you can make sure they're not in the middle of changing exhibits - at that time, there won't be much to see.
If you are into the arts and have a day to spare when you visit Beijing, this is a place worth visiting as it showcases a large range of art works from China and around the world.

The entrance is for free, passport is needed, but no one warned us there was a reconstruction going on and most of the floors were closed to public. In the remaining floors majority of art is Chinese calligraphy only without any English description or materials. Since we spent a lot of time getting there, it was a great disappointment and a waste of time. Definitely would not recommend to someone who has limited amount of time for Beijing, there is much more to see than this.

"Lee Young Jun PEN ART"

Pen Art(General Remarks)

Infinity of lines and dots have symbolism.  Such symbolism is ever changing according to the spirit’s depth.  All works are kaleidoscopic; they are usually composed of indescribable expressions.  Therefore, art’s depth also can be said to be unlimited.  Is pen art’s depth also infinite?  In other words, do the lines and dots flowing from the nib of a pen have an artistic qualification?  In this respect, it is worth thinking deeply.  Pen art begins from an essence of nature’s fundamental values.  From the standpoint of value, or color, a harmony of black and white is essential in nature.  As it is impossible to see any color in darkness, distinguishing color is an essential role of light.  That is why the soul is drawn to light.  Whiteness, or light is a spiritual reflection of the soul while blackness, or darkness is a reality of life on earth.  As the color green is an essential color of vegetation, burnt charcoal is an earthy color that will stay near black.  Blackness is heterogeneous and may be hostile to life.  If blackness belongs to the essence of nature, it also may be said to represent the image of death.  A combination of black and white constitutes degrees of lightness and darkness.  When painting black on a white background, the soul is transported to the white background.  Whiteness comes to life when contrasted with black line and black space.  In this case, soul also may be expressed through the blackness.  Soul may be transported to the black or a combination of white and black, which shed a mysterious merit to the soul or spirit.  Pen arts starts and ends from an essence of nature’s fundamental contrasts.  The primary essence is infinite and eternal while the artistic harmony of black and white can take one’s breath away.  But, this is not possible until a metamorphosis has been realized over many years and spiritual transcendence has occurred.  The transfer of spirit  occurs when one’s life experiences are projected onto the white canvas in harmony with blackness.  That is the true ‘pen art.’               
                Artist  Lee Young Jun

It's directly accessible from exit D of the Dongsi Shitiao metro station on line 2. Purchase your tickets from the concierges desk in main lobby. The museum is on the 9th floor of the New Poly Plaza.  All items are beautifully arranged, behind glass with a direct spotlight, with simple English names but there's no further English text about the details. I wasn't offered an audio, but on the name plates of the displayed pieces, there was a headset symbol. It's a compact museum specifically focused on recovered relics from overseas. The main showcase is the 4 zodiac fountainheads (pig, monkey, tiger,  and ox) that were ransacked from the Old Summer Palace in 1860. This gives interest to going to the Old Summer Palace. If you are interested in seeing the 3 other recovered fountainheads: rat and rabbit are housed in the National Museum, and the horse is housed in the Capital Museum. Next door to the Poly building is the Nanxincang Culture and Leisure Street. It's worth a stroll.

The Beijing Ancient Observatory, on the UNESCO Tentative List, is located on the top of a fort-like building at Jianguo Gate. It is one of the oldest observatories in the world. It used to be a part of the city wall once surrounding Beijing.

Although there were no telescopes at this observatory, there were many sophisticated instruments for taking astronomical measurements, introduced in the 17th century from Western Europe. 

Here are eight bronze instruments constructed in the Qing dynasty. Six of them were built by the Flemish Jesuit Ferdinand Verbiest (1623–88) in 1669. The first was constructed by the Portuguese Jesuit Kilian Stumpf (1655–1720) between 1713 and 1715, while the maker of the latter is not clear. 

The seven instruments made by the two Jesuits are based on Tycho Brahe’s design but with Chinese decorations, while the last one belongs to the Chinese tradition but with a European system of graduation and sighting. Overall, the observatory is now the only example in the world that is equipped with Tychonic instruments.

It's directly accessible from exit C of the Jianguomen metro station on line 1 or 2. The observatory houses the old astronomical equipment. The information sign is sparse on details. On clear days, this is a nice viewing area. There are 3 exhibition halls on the ground level have details on ancient time keeping instruments and constellation recordings. Only an hour is needed for the visit.

Lived in Beijing for 4years, great place to eat when you want and if you're a group of 6+ people or if you have friends visiting. I highly recommend to book in advance to have a table in the garden if you go there in rush hours or you'll wait a really ling time. Please insist to have it in the garden when booking! Our tour took us to Hua's Courtyard Restaurant for its highly rated Peking Duck.  IMO, Hua's famous Peking Duck is overhyped, more on presentation than flavor.

Nice place, the food is good and the people are extremely kind!

New location!  No. 88 Baochao.  Well worth the 20 min walk from the subway.  Our kids (ages 7-15) loved the food: the dumplings, sweet and sour shrimp, black pepper beef, and noodles with green beans were all incredible.  Awesome price/value meal in a really cool old hutong neighborhood.

Clearly designed for the foreign customers, Mr Shi’s has very good dumplings… But at 86RMB for 12, it was a bit expensive compared to other dumpling restaurants, thus my 4 star rating instead of 5. Either way, $13 surely is not going to break the bank, so I would say check it out!

Dumplings are great! Huge selection! (fried are better )

Dumplings were ok, decent. It’s tourist price and they even charge you 2rmb (per person) for using their plates and cutleries! I find that a bit ridiculous considering their meals are already priced on the high side
Fresh dumplings served in a timely manner. Didn't have to wait long. Also nice hide out, very cozy.

Well-appointed hotel with easy access to the airport expressway (although I'm very grateful that I didn't have to drive...). Staff were very friendly and accommodating. Breakfast buffet offered a wide selection of Chinese and Western menu items. Executive lounge had a nice layout, but a limited selection of items on offer; only drinks during the day, but apparently appetizers are served in the evenings.

Great location with nice staffs. Large clean room with a king bed but would be better to have hotter water for shower. I know that warm water is better for your skin but I need to have a hot shower after a long air travel.

Although it was a beautiful hotel it wasn't the service you'd expect from a Marriott. After I arrived from my flight there was nobody to welcome me at the door or help me unload the bags from my taxi. After I got up to the check in counter they couldn't find my reservations in their system which was frustrating as they demanded I call the booking site and deal with this. After talking to the booking site they confirmed yes I was booked for the room, yes it was for the exact room and dates and free breakfast, they even called the Marriott hotel head office and confirmed yes the booking was valid and the issue was on the hotels side not mine or Marriott's side. After nearly 3 hrs of talking with the hotel they finally checked me into a room that the shower didn't even turn on and was not heated. They had to send up serval workmen to fix it and didn't offer anything for all the problems they've caused me. Honestly for the price you can get a lot better local hotels. I wouldn't stay here again and would recommend nobody else does unless they get more international speakers and start upholding the same standards that are to be expected from all Marriott hotels.

one of the most wonderful parks I've ever been to! 当然 worth visiting!

I have been to the park for over thirty years. It is now free for everyone. A nice and large park with river, lakes, playground, and paved trails everywhere. People come here to relax, play, or do some group activities. Enjoy the water, green, and fresh air.

It's a 200m walk (5 min) from exit D of the National Library metro station on line 4 or 9. The park is large so it's a long walk around the lake, but the landscape is very beautiful. A lot of walkers and runners use the main path. You can find less traveled side paths through the bamboo forests. It's winter time, so there are no lake activities. The giant duck demands attention. I like the lotus bridge. It's a stone bridge that zigzags along the shore of the lake for about 100m; at each zigzag point, there is a seating area in the shape of a lotus flower.

大钟寺是觉生寺的俗称，现在已经有300多岁了。因为寺院里珍藏着永乐大钟，所以现在这里成为了古钟博物馆。镇馆之宝“永乐大钟”，钟体很大，比鼓楼的永乐大钟还高出1.2米，重量达到46.5吨，光是悬挂起来就费足了功夫。不仅如此，大钟上面刻满了汉文和梵文的一百多种佛教经咒，细细数下来，有23万多字！后来有音乐专家测试过这口大钟的音色，非常浑厚和响亮，相当于A调，声音可以传播到十里地开外，尾音保持70秒钟。

大鐘寺古鐘博物館とも言う。
鐘の博物館、昔の大鐘がたくさん展示してある。よく見ると鐘の表面一面に漢字がある面白いものもある。
中国の鐘だけでなく西洋や日本の鐘の展示もあり、ちゃんと博物館らしくなっている。

八角游乐园站位于北京市石景山区，是北京地铁1号线上的车站之一，编号是105。1971年11月7日，北京地铁一期工程运营区段线路由北京站至玉泉路站延长到古城路站运营时投入运营。本站原名为八角村站，1986年八角游乐园建成后，更改为现有站名。此站临近石景山游乐园和老山城市休闲公园。
田义墓在北京石景山区法海寺西南500米处，是目前中国保存最完好、规格最高、石刻最精美的明代太监墓。

田义（1534－1605年），别号渭川，陕西华阴县人。9岁入宫，在宫廷生活63年，经历了嘉靖、隆庆、万历三朝，由于办事“周慎简重，练达老成”，所以“历事三朝未尝有过”，并且“始终宠遇不衰，禄米岁增”，最终官至司礼监掌印太监。明刘若愚《酌中志》称其“贞介忠诚，有大臣度……性俭朴寡言，休休有量，人不敢干以私”。田义墓中宦官墓群林立，正是因为在田义死后，同朝宦官钦佩其为人，同时羡慕蟠龙山前这块风水宝地（马荣墓碑中曾描绘墓北“有山如龙，嵯峨屏峙，林峦秀丽”），因而愿意伴其左右。墓园建于明万历三十三年（1605年），占地约0.6公顷，由神道区、享堂区和寿域区三大部分组成，形成“前方后圆”的格局——神道区、享堂区为两重方形庭院，寿域区平面呈半圆形。整个墓园建筑群背倚曲折延绵的蟠龙山，面对模式口老街，依山就势，沿南北中轴线布局，由南至北顺次为神道门、华表、石像生、棂星门、碑亭、享殿遗址、寿域门、石供桌、墓碑、宝顶等，为研究明代墓葬制度的重要实例。
在冰川遗址上建立的展览馆，可以看到很多化石和石头。十个场馆里面的一些互动的设备都处于关机状态。在山上而且路过居民区，道路很窄。

Great park situated around a large lake that offers boat rides. Its a great place to view locals performing various types of arts. The location is near the Forbidden Palace, but is far enough where you can enjoy time away from the crowds. Highly recommended.

This is the park that has the white dragon pagoda. A pagoda is simply a tower that has an ancient relic within it. Going up to the pagoda is a great place to start but what really takes your breath away is the lake! There is a huge lake with lily pads and they have boats that take you all around the lake. It was so peaceful and serene.

Nice park but very different from UK parks. It's huge so it'll take a while to walk up every part. It's very tidy and well maintained. Not great for kids though as walking on the grass or climbing the rocks is not allowed. It's very popular (crowded) with locals as well as tourists, especially on weekends. The lake provides plenty of space for the hundreds of paddle boats.
Highly recommended! To me this is better than the Summer Palace and it’s right in the city! Explore so many hidden gems walking around the entire place!

A breathtakingly beautiful place at sunset and a stroll around was one of the highlights of my trip to Beijing.

There were a substantial amount of tourists taking photos, so it can be difficult to take a good shot with your camera at these peak times. Perhaps sunrise would be quieter and a good opportunity for an iconic photo.

There were some little paddlers I saw chained up at the waters edge which I assume can be used during sunny days.

Well worth stopping by if you are a tourist in Beijing.

From this park, we can see the whole The Forbidden City. It is famous because of its position, as well as its history. The last ruler of the Ming dynasty, committed suicide by hanging himself from a tree in Jingshan. Prepare your health before walking to its top.
You can stand on the center point of Beijing City from this park.

Love this park and the walk up the steps to the temple is a WORK OUT! Make sure to bring walking shoes, water and a camera! Beautiful views once you male it to the top. We went during Chinese New Year and it was pretty crowded.
Nice wiev over the forbidden city. It is clean and preserved park. Good experience after we could not reach forbidden city. And it is for 10 yuan so the price is not so high.
Immediately north of the Forbidden City, this park has a cheap entry ticket and a spectacular view of the surrounding area. Its the best place to view the Forbidden city's true scale.

If you like views, then this is the place for you. Jingshan Park is probably my favourite place to go to in Beijing. You can start off at Tian'anmen Square, go North through the Forbidden City, and then cross the road to Jingshan Park. The walk to the top of the park will take you probably 5-10 minutes, but it's definitely worth it. You'll be able to see 360 views of Beijing for miles. The best time to go is during the week as it can get pretty crowded at the weekend.

Price: 10RMB

Leave the Forbidden City's North gate and go left underground to get to the Park's South Gate.

北京廣化寺，位於北京市西城區什剎海北邊的鴉兒胡同31號，是一座大型佛教寺院。

廣化寺始建於元代，傳說是一高僧托缽化緣、籌措布施所建，寺亦因此得名。明天順七年（1463年）重建過一次。明萬曆年間、清咸豐十二年（1852年）重修，光緒二十年（1894年）重建。1937年溥儒（名畫家溥心畬）曾出資修整。

廣化寺在明代為淨土宗廟，清道光年改為子孫剃度廟。宣統元年（1909年）由清學部主持在廣化寺籌建京師圖書館（原北京圖書館前身），民國時期魯迅作為教育部主管圖書館工作的社會教育司第一科科長，常來此工作。1917年京師圖書館從廣化寺遷至方家胡同國子監南學。1921年8月廣化寺對外開放。1927年，北平的南、北兩個佛教會合併，設會址於廣化寺。1939年在此創辦廣化佛學院，1946年建廣化小學。1982年北京佛教協會成立並將會址設在此寺，1985年寺內成立北京佛教樂團。現為北京市佛教協會和北京佛教音樂團辦公活動場所，北京市文物保護單位。

1947年，當時廣化主持玉山和尚倡議，組織廣化小學董事會，在廣化寺廟內成立了廣化小學，校長為修明和尚。修明和尚曾去法國留學，攻讀文學專業，後因故出家當了和尚，1949年後還一度出任大學教授，後來因為身體不好，又回到廣化寺當和尚。廣化小學開始辦的是兩個初級班，當時免交學費，並供給書本文具等。後逐漸健全為六年制的小學。1952年接管後，與私立崇實第二小學和競業小學合併，改為鴉兒胡同小學分校，是第二批接管的市立小學。1957年為了保護古建，學校遷至廣化寺後院的彌陀庵院內（鼓樓西大街63號）直至今日。

廣化寺整體院落保持完好，建築共分五路。除一般寺廟的中、東、西路以外，又在兩旁增建東二路和西二路，是院落更顯得宏闊而嚴整。寺院南側有影壁，向北為山門殿，匾額書「敕賜廣化寺」五個金粉大字。山門內東西兩側為鐘樓、鼓樓，中為天王殿、大雄寶殿和藏經閣。藏經閣位於寺院後部，是一個二層罩樓，閣內藏有珍貴的明清兩種刻本《大藏經》7部。各殿均有配殿，西側兩路各有二進院落，有觀音閣、地藏閣、方丈室、法堂、祖堂等。東路尚存二層殿，其餘均已拆改。

寺內有石碑4通。一些書法時石刻嵌於廊壁。1989年重修頤和園佛香閣時曾從寺內移去一尊大佛，並舉行開光升座典禮。寺廟內保存一批藏經、佛畫、碑刻、僧人影像及名人字畫等珍貴文物。

每逢農曆初一和十五，廣化寺都有法事活動。每個周六北京佛教音樂團在廣化寺都有演奏活動。每年農曆的臘八，廣化寺都要熬粥免費發放給到寺的市民，這一傳統從建寺起延續至今。

1989年8月16日（農曆七月十五）廣化寺舉行開光、升座典禮，信眾400餘人到寺祝賀大佛移至頤和園佛香閣。

北京广化寺，位于北京市西城区什刹海北边的鸦儿胡同31号，是一座大型佛教寺院。广化寺始建于元代，传说是一高僧托钵化缘、筹措布施所建，寺亦因此得名。明天顺七年（1463年）重建过一次。明万历年间、清咸丰十二年（1852年）重修，光绪二十年（1894年）重建。1937年溥儒（名画家溥心畬）曾出资修整。
始建於元代的十方叢林.
中國北京城

It's a 600 m walk (10 min) from exit A of the Xisi metro station on line 4. This temple highlights the profiles of ancient emperors in China's history. As noted on the info board, "by the end of Qianlong period of the Qing dynasty, there had been 188 emperors". It's a bit tiresome to read each profile. My motivation was zapped after a few profile reads. There's also family name records traced along ancestral lines. This is interesting for those doing genealogy. Some buildings have a very sparse museum of pottery and statues
Amazing history and amazing culture
历代帝王庙位于阜成门内大街北侧，坐北朝南。中轴线上自南至北原来依次为影壁、石桥、庙门、景德门、景德崇圣殿、祭器库。其中景德崇圣殿为正殿，其东西两侧共有四座御碑亭，以及东西配殿。历代帝王庙西院还有一座“庙中庙”——关帝庙。
蠻值得參訪的地方, 但若有人引導你去買玉製品或其他寶石, 建議不要買。
Espectacular

The Forbidden City in miniature version. Easier to visit, just as beautiful as his "big brother", and unfortunately just as busy. So make sure you get there early if you want to look around at leisure, because it is really worth a visit.

Wonderful plave that took me back in time to the imperial era. So many wonderful buildings and peices art and beautiful gardens. I wish everone on earth had the possibilty to come here to expreince this for themselves

A lovely place to witness wonderful piece of Ancient Chinese Architecture and Chinese Wealthy Living Style. 

I was told it will take nearly half a day for complete visit with Audio Listening. There are plenty of Buildings, Landscapes, etc. I spent just 2 hours only in the complex. 

Most interesting part is the story behind this Mansion, Richness, Royalty, End of most Corrupted Person, etc.
A market with more locals than tourist. Prices aren't that expensive and really nice view.
from my personal opinion, this place might be suitable for someone that has read and quite familiar with Lu'xun book prior, that will be more useful and appreciated.
Many artifacts and details from Lu Xun's life in a nice setting. There is a decent amount of English, although obviously a lot more detail in Chinese. Very interesting.

It's a 350 m walk (5 min) from exit B of the Fuchengmen metro station on line 2. Free admittance. The Lu Xun museum was bare. I was expecting many artifacts and details from Lu Xun's life. Probably it is in transition. Currently there is an oddly placed exhibit on Liaonan shadow puppet theater. You can only enter the courtyard and backyard of the residence. The windows are clean to allow a view into the buildings. It's a quick visit that you can pair with visiting Miaoying Temple (White Stupa Temple)

北京鲁迅博物馆包括展馆和故居两部分。
鲁迅故居是一座精巧的四合院，是鲁迅在北京最后也是最重要的一处住所。四合院内包含南房三间、北房四间以及东西厢房。其中最著名是就是鲁迅在北房后面接出来的一间“老虎尾巴”，这间不足十平米的斗室，是鲁迅先生自己的设计，作为他的工作室兼卧室，可以保证采光时间，以及眺望后面园子里的风景。“在我的后园，可以看见墙外有两株树，一株是枣树，还有一株也是枣树”，鲁迅在《秋夜》当中写到的这两棵枣树，虽然现在已经没有了，但是他亲手栽种的白丁香，还在后院里静静开放。
鲁迅博物馆的部分则面积较大，分为地面和地下两层，一共收集了三万多件珍贵的文物，包括鲁迅在仙台学医科时候的解刨学笔记、《阿Q正传》唯一的一篇残稿、鲁迅收藏的藏书和拓片等等。博物馆的布展按照鲁迅先生的地理足迹来作为不同章节，从绍兴到日本，从北京到上海，非常清晰。

魯迅が北京時代に住んだ家です。
魯迅は１９２４年５月に越してきてから、三・一八事件に連座して北京を追われるまで ２年間あまりをこの家ですごしました。伝統的な四合院のつくりで、北側の小さな一室が魯迅の書斎兼寝室だったところ。中庭には、 魯迅が手ずから植えた３本のライラックの木があり、いまも春になるとかぐわしい香りがあたりに漂うそうです。 故居の東側に魯迅博物館が併設されており、２万点以上にのぼる関連資料の他、魯迅の蔵書１万３０００冊余りが 納められています。蔵書の背中を見ているだけで、時間が過ぎていくのを忘れてしましそうになりました。
住所は西城区阜成門内西三条胡同２１号

프렌즈베이징보고갔는데 한국인입맛에는 잘안맞는거같아요 ㅠㅠ 중국여행 세번째고 위샹로우쓰도 좋아하는데 여기서는 그것마저도 입에안맞았음...유일하게 훈툰 맛있게먹고 나머지는 거의 남기고 나왔습니다. 가격대는 타식당에비해 높은편이에요! (마파두부가 46원) 요리엄청빨리나오고 서비스는 괜찮아요. 현금은 영수증들고 카운터직접가서 계산해야돼요. 저녁7시에갔는데 웨이팅은 5분정도함!
Ottima anatra laccata. Servizio impeccabile
口感新鲜，食材味美，小情调环境感觉很温馨很快乐。推荐大家可以来试一试，不存在什么吵闹嘈杂，安心吃饭就好。

The taste of mutton is similar to what my mom makes at home. The skewers are not as good as those from less known restaurants. As a native tbh I don't see why this is labeled intangible cultural heritage.
One of my best. Nice moments (2x), good meal and nice place around.
Nice place and easy to get here from Subway. However, food is overpriced even though the taste is good.
Great restaurant located in one of my favorite places in Beijing. The beef and lamb are so tender... absolutely delicious

very authentic experience given my first time in beijing, you will definitely not miss it as you wander down this street as there would be lines of people getting their hands and mouths dirty while attempting to eat from the lamb skewers. The meat is succulent and flavorful and i highly recommend the lamb meat, do bath it in the chili powder for an extra oomph.
Amazing.

Nice meals and traditional Chinese environment. Every body is good at their job. It is a little bit show business. Foods taste good. I recommend this place. Central location and good to visit. The shop around are closed a little bit early. That is why, first shop then eat...

Nice place. Good and fresh food. Acceptable prices. Vegi dishes

I truly enjoyed visiting the Forbidden City during my travels to Beijing! China has such a rich history and you can truly step right into the culture by visiting this historic site. It is massive so you can literally spend a good part of your day in there and still not see everything. Be aware that tickets sell out extremely fast so be sure to arrive very early to secure your entrance. Our tour guide told us that 80,000 people visit the Forbidden City daily! I highly recommend this tourist site for your Beijing travels!

A marvelous place. You gonna spend hours in this place. Hundreds of buildings, landscapes,  stairs, gardens, all well preserved.  The stores inside sell articles, drinks and food for a reasonable price.  Foreigners must buy the ticket that costs RMB 40 in March. Don't forget you passport, and don't carry any forbidden stuff. The security is very effective.

This is probably one of the most famous landmarks in Beijing. The historic and cultural significance of this place makes this without a doubt, a must visit place for any tourist. The sprawling grounds that are opened to visitors are quite well kept considering the age and massive amounts of human traffic. We engaged an official guide, not one of the touts standing around, and had a blast listening to the various stories as we walked around. For the unfamiliar, a guide is the way to go, as the place is huge, and you get to ask questions. 

We spent nearly a full day there, and had to still skip some of the exhibitions inside that requires payment. Yes, on top of the entrance fee, there are exhibitions here and there that requires a small fee as well. Don't be daunted by the tight security, and massive crowds, as this is really one of those places you have to see at the very least once in your life.

It wasn't caked the Forbidden City for nothing... Opulence at its grandest... In the heart of Beijing.
Its a must see!!
Expect to spend at least half a day inside of you want to get a good understanding of the place.
One can buy tickets at the counter on the left just before the entrance, by showing your passport... Wasn't trouble at all.

Here is our very negative experience - never travel here at bank holiday ... We come at Saturday lunch time to find out that the tickets were sold out ... The service guys told us to come at 8 next day that there is 1000 tickets at the window. Otherwise you can buy tickets online but for that you need to have Chinese bank account and still there is just 80K tickets in total. So we come Sunday at 7 to find out a lot of people but still we was between the first ones. After waiting one hour they start to let people in just to find out that the tickets are sold out again. Even we clearly saw some locals buy tickets. The guards laugh to our face and did not let us in ... So we basically did not saw forbidden city but our experience with it is very bad ...

The stores inside sell articles, drinks and food for a reasonable price.  Foreigners must buy the ticket that costs RMB 40 in March. Don't forget you passport, and don't carry any forbidden stuff. The security is very effective.

This is probably one of the most famous landmarks in Beijing. The historic and cultural significance of this place makes this without a doubt, a must visit place for any tourist. The sprawling grounds that are opened to visitors are quite well kept considering the age and massive amounts of human traffic. We engaged an official guide, not one of the touts standing around, and had a blast listening to the various stories as we walked around. For the unfamiliar, a guide is the way to go, as the place is huge, and you get to ask questions. 

We spent nearly a full day there, and had to still skip some of the exhibitions inside that requires payment. Yes, on top of the entrance fee, there are exhibitions here and there that requires a small fee as well. Don't be daunted by the tight security, and massive crowds, as this is really one of those places you have to see at the very least once in your life.

It wasn't caked the Forbidden City for nothing... Opulence at its grandest... In the heart of Beijing.
Its a must see!!
Expect to spend at least half a day inside of you want to get a good understanding of the place.
One can buy tickets at the counter on the left just before the entrance, by showing your passport... Wasn't trouble at all.

Here is our very negative experience - never travel here at bank holiday ... We come at Saturday lunch time to find out that the tickets were sold out ... The service guys told us to come at 8 next day that there is 1000 tickets at the window. Otherwise you can buy tickets online but for that you need to have Chinese bank account and still there is just 80K tickets in total. So we come Sunday at 7 to find out a lot of people but still we was between the first ones. After waiting one hour they start to let people in just to find out that the tickets are sold out again. Even we clearly saw some locals buy tickets. The guards laugh to our face and did not let us in ... So we basically did not saw forbidden city but our experience with it is very bad ...
